Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2013 10:55AM Bighair wrote: You would be surprised at the number of docs who don't realize that lobular often goes to the abdomen area first.  Mine went to my stomach (and was originally dianosed as stomach cancer) and is now in my liver and bones.  My doc doesn't place a lot of emphasis on the tumor marker tests, and relies mainly on the scans.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2013 12:58PM Bighair wrote: Please include me:  Bighair
Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 12:26PM Bighair wrote: When I hear miracle stories, I usually find that the teller is short on facts, has the facts wrong, or is simply unversed in what the crucial facts to ask are.  People who haven't had cancer don't understand the nuances.  One friend told me, "so & so has had Stage 4 BC for 15 years".  Turns out, she had stage 2 in the beginning and has had stage 4 for five years--my friend didn't understand the difference between stage 2 and 4.  I don't believe in miracles.  I believe in science.  There are many things we don't know about cancer and this explains the inconsistencies.  Hearing that "so & so had a miraculous recovery" can make you feel hurt and angry that you haven't had one.
Posts.Title: What do you make of the miracle stories? Skream DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 11:36AM Bighair wrote: I was diagnosed with Stage 4 ILC with mets to the stomach lining, liver and bones.  I'm on Femara and my tumor markers have declined and scans show stable disease.  I don't know what to expect with regard to my stomach.  For now, everything is working well.  I eat almost anything I want (although less of it) and have a bowel movement every day.  I have found that surgeons often offer the worst case scenario, and are often wrong.  Good luck to you and your mom.
Posts.Title: Dismal talk with surgeon luvmimom Judi1952
